Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Research and Education for a Solar Future: Fundamentals of Nanocrystal Photochemistry and Integration of Solar Energy Research into Physical Chemistry Curriculum
Award.AbstractNarration:
Prof. Gordana Dukovic of the University of Colorado Boulder is supported through a CAREER award by the Supramolecular, Macromolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division to study the photochemistry of semiconductor nanocrystals. These materials have intriguing potential applications related to driving chemical reactions with visible light. However, the mechanisms of photochemical reactions mediated by semiconductor nanocrystals are poorly understood. The aim of this project is to correlate nanocrystal structural parameters with photochemical reaction mechanisms and provide a rational basis for the design of practical materials. Prof. Dukovic will also develop an educational program that integrates current research problems in solar energy harvesting into the curriculum for undergraduate Physical Chemistry (Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy).

This project will improve the fundamental understanding of how nanocrystals can facilitate useful light-driven chemical reactions. The scientific discoveries will impact exciting potential applications of nanoscale semiconductors in technologies of broad interest (e.g., solar fuel generation, environmental remediation and disinfection). The educational program that integrates solar energy research with teaching of quantum mechanics and spectroscopy will be disseminated to the education community so that it can be replicated in college classrooms. The program will showcase researchers from diverse backgrounds, which will encourage participation of students from underrepresented groups in scientific careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: With the support of this grant, Dukovic and coworkers worked on elucidating the fundamental photophysics and photochemistry of II-VI semiconductor nanocrystals. Some highlights include: (i) Ultra-short single atom S2-, Se2-, and Te2- ligands create semiconductor-like single-atom shells around CdSe and CdTe quantum dots (QDs), enabling delocalization of electron and hole wavefunctions, but they also strongly impact the excited state dynamics of these nanocrystals by changing the electron trap landscape. They also strongly impact the relaxation of acoustic phonons in nanocrystals. (ii) Trapped holes in CdS and CdSe nanocrystals are not stationary, as usually assumed, but instead move by random walk diffusion on nanocrystal surfaces. This provides a pathway for them to find adsorbed hole acceptors on the surface and impacts photooxidation chemistry. (iii) Due to trapped hole diffusion, long-lived excited states are created in CdSe/CdS and ZnSe/CdS dot-in-rod nanostructures. These states arise from morphology, rather than energy level alignment alone.  (iv) We investigated the charge transfer between nanocrystals and water reduction and oxidation catalysts and related those dynamics with the overall photochemistry. In particular, we discovered an extremely fast transfer of photoexcited holes from CdS nanocrystals to a water oxidation catalyst, as well as a slower transfer of trapped holes.

Broader Impacts: The research results obtained in the course of this project have an impact on our understanding of solar photochemistry, potentially impacting renewable energy applications. Several graduate and undergraduate students participated in this project. Two of the graduate students were awarded NSF Graduate Research Fellowships, and another two obtained tenure-track positions at primarily undergraduate institutions. Prof. Dukovic developed a number of learning modules for undergraduate physical chemistry that incorporate solar energy research into the quantum mechanics and spectroscopy curriculum. 

Publications Resulting from the Award: 11 peer-reviewed publications.
